{{ukmotorwayAsmall|1}} }} {{kml}} The '''A15''' is a major [[road]] in [[England]]. It runs north from [[Peterborough]] via [[Market Deeping]], [[Bourne, Lincolnshire|Bourne]], [[Sleaford]] and [[Lincoln, England|Lincoln]] along a variety of ancient, Roman, and Turnpike alignments before it is interrupted at its junction with the [[M180 motorway|M180]] near [[Scawby]]. The road restarts {{convert|10|mi}} east, and then continues north past [[Barton-upon-Humber]], crossing the [[Humber]] on the [[Humber Bridge]] before terminating at [[Hessle]] near [[Kingston upon Hull]]. ==Driving conditions== According to [[The Automobile Association|the AA]], the route is {{convert|95|mi|km}} long, and should take 2{{fraction|1|4}} hours. Norman Cross – Bourne takes 33 minutes, Bourne to Lincoln takes 46 minutes and Lincoln to the Humber Bridge takes 54 minutes. A section of the A15 (between [[Scampton]] and the M180) provides the longest stretch of straight road in the UK.{{cite book|last1=Freestone|first1=Nigel|title=Ultimate British Roads and Motorways Quiz Book : 200 Questions on Road and Motorway History|date=2013|publisher=Andrews UK|isbn=9781909949805|page=3}}{{cite web|last1=Hucker|first1=Richard Adrian|title=How Did the Romans Achieve Straight Roads?|url=https://www.fig.net/resources/proceedings/fig_proceedings/fig2009/papers/hs01/hs01_hucker_3471.pdf|website=Fig.net|accessdate=14 June 2016|page=1|format=PDF}} ==Route== ===Peterborough=== {{main article|Road transport in Peterborough}} [[File:London Road Towards Fletton - geograph.org.uk - 976670.jpg|thumb|left|London Road looking north under the A1139 at Fletton]][[File:A15 Queensgate (Dec 2012).jpg|thumb|left|The A15 dual carriageway at [[Queensgate shopping centre, United Kingdom|Queensgate Shopping Centre]]]] [[File:A15 Peterborough (City Centre) Dec 2012.jpg|thumb|left|The A15 dual carrigeway in the city centre.]] The A15 is Peterborough's main connecting road from the south to the [[A1 road (Great Britain)|A1(M)]], joining{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/885179 |title=Cycle Route|work=OS grid TL1690|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} near [[Stilton]], at [[Norman Cross]]. It begins as ''London Road'' at junction{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/885202 |title=Brick Patterns, Norman Cross|work=OS grid TL1590|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} 16 of the A1(M) with the B1043 (former A1) in [[Cambridgeshire]] and the district of [[North West Cambridgeshire]]. From here to [[Yaxley, Cambridgeshire|Yaxley]] it passes the ''Norman Cross Hotel''{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/885173 |title=Norman Cross Hotel|work=OS grid TL1590|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} and follows{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/379714 |title=London Road Yaxley|work=OS grid TL1792|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} the City of Peterborough and Cambridgeshire boundary, where there is a junction with the B1091 (for [[Farcet]]). It enters the City of Peterborough near [[Hampton, Peterborough|Hampton Vale]] on the left, and meets the A1260 ''The Serpentine'', which leads to two much faster routes around Peterborough. Next is a roundabout for the Cygnet Park business park on the left, home of the new headquarters of [[News International]]. It enters [[Old Fletton]] near the headquarters of [[Hotpoint]] to the left. There is a staggered junction with the A1129 and it crosses the [[East Coast Main Line]]. It passes{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/83410 |title=London Road, Peterborough|work=OS grid TL1997|publisher=Geograph project |date=23 November 2005 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] on the right in [[New Fletton]]. It meets the start of the [[A605 road|A605]] at a roundabout and crosses the [[River Nene]]. [[File:15 Meets 47 - geograph.org.uk - 322311.jpg|thumb|The [[A47 road|A47]] junction near [[Dogsthorpe, Peterborough|Dogsthorpe]] ]] The A15 takes two routes through Peterborough: * The route on the west side begins as ''Bourges Boulevard''{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/465153 |title=Covered footbridge across Bourges Boulevard|work=OS grid TL1898|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} at Peterborough [[Crown Court]], meets the A1179 (former A47), passes the [[Peterborough railway station]] and meets three roundabouts near [[Millfield, Peterborough|Millfield]] and [[New England, Peterborough|New England]]. It follows the East Coast Main Line and becomes ''Lincoln Road'' and ''Werrington Parkway''{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/672644 |title=Pedestrian crossing|work=OS grid TF1504|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} after the A47 [[Grade separation|GSJ]]. It passes four roundabouts, crossing the [[Peterborough to Lincoln Line]]. * The route on the east side starts at the ''[[Eye, Cambridgeshire|Eye]]'' roundabout{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/354159 |title=Eye roundabout, Peterborough|work=OS grid TF2101|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} with the A1139 at [[Newark, Peterborough|Newark]], then follows the dual-carriageway ''Paston Parkway'', which meets{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/322311 |title=15 Meets 47|work=OS grid TF2002|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} the A47. It continues as a dual-carriageway (opened in spring 2008) at the next roundabout at [[Gunthorpe, Peterborough|Gunthorpe]] and follows the [[Car Dyke]] then meets another roundabout at Werrington before becoming a single carriageway and crosses the Spalding railway between [[Werrington, Peterborough|Werrington]] and [[Glinton, Cambridgeshire|Glinton]] . [[File:Pedestrian crossing - geograph.org.uk - 672644.jpg|thumb|Approaching the [[Glinton, Cambridgeshire|Glinton]] bypass from the south]] Both routes head through [[Werrington, Peterborough|Werrington]] (passing either side) before joining again at [[Glinton, Cambridgeshire|Glinton]] with the roundabout with the B1443. There is another roundabout.{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/162377 |title=Glinton Bypass|work=OS grid TF1405|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} with the B1443 (for [[Helpston]]). It passes [[Etton, Cambridgeshire|Etton]] and meets a roundabout with the B1524{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/442601 |title=The B1524, Lincoln Road|work=OS grid TF1408|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} (former route through Market Deeping), B1162 (for [[Northborough, Cambridgeshire|Northborough]] to the right) and an exit for [[Maxey, Cambridgeshire|Maxey]] to the right. ===Kesteven=== Just south of the ''Welland Gate'' roundabout on the [[A1175 road|A1175]] and B1166, it crosses the [[River Welland]] so entering [[South Kesteven]] in [[Lincolnshire]]. The roundabout marks the western end of the £7 million {{convert|4|mi|adj=on}} [[Market Deeping]] bypass, finished in July 1998. The A15 and A1175 roads are now merged in a {{convert|1|mi|adj=on}} dual-carriageway stretch. It meets the B1524 (former route) at a roundabout and heads to the left as ''Peterborough Road''{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/453491 |title=becoming |publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} ''Bourne Road'' and ''Deeping Road''. [[File:The A15 Peterborough Road, Langtoft, Lincs - geograph.org.uk - 453491.jpg|thumb|Entering [[Langtoft, Lincolnshire|Langtoft]] from the south]] North of Baston is the Waterside Garden Centre{{cite web|url=http://www.begardenhappy.com/watersidegardencentre |title=Garden Centre Peterborough | Waterside Garden Centre |publisher=BeGardenHappy | accessdate=11 May 2013}} close to where it meets the north-south [[Roman roads in Britain|Roman Road]] [[King Street (Roman road)|King Street]], which it follows until just north of Bourne. It goes over the [[River Glen, Lincolnshire|River Glen]] at the point it is crossed by the [[Macmillan Way]], at [[Kate's Bridge]]. There is a left turn for [[Obthorpe]] and it goes through [[Thurlby by Bourne|Thurlby]], passing the ''Horseshoe''{{cite web|url=http://www.thehorseshoethurlby.co.uk |title=About us |publisher=Thehorseshoethurlby.co.uk | accessdate=11 May 2013}} pub, then [[Northorpe, South Kesteven|Northorpe]], before coming to the small town of [[Bourne, Lincolnshire|Bourne]]. It meets the recently diverted [[A151 road|A151]] at a new roundabout (the A151 leaves to the right {{convert|100|m|yd|order=flip}} further on), where the road becomes ''South Road''. It passes [[Bourne Grammar School]], then after some treacherous bends near [[Bourne Abbey]] becomes ''South Street'', with the town's Heritage centre{{cite web|title=Baldock's Mill|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/149927|publisher=Geograph project|accessdate=3 December 2013}} and war memorial gardens on the left by the [[Bourne Eau]].{{cite web|title=Bourne Eau and memorial gardens|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/404360|publisher=Geograph project|accessdate=3 December 2013}} At the crossroads in the centre of town it crosses the B1193 (original route of the A151) in the historic market place({{coord|52|46.0920|N|0|22.6320|W|region:GB|display=inline|format=dms|name=Bourne, Lincolnshire cross roads}}), where are located the ''Nags Head'', ''Angel Hotel'', ''Burghley Arms''.{{cite web|url=http://homepages.which.net/~rex/bourne/burghleyarms.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-01-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070711032415/http://homepages.which.net/~rex/bourne/burghleyarms.htm |archivedate=11 July 2007 }} {{cite web|title=Bourne town centre|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/96987|publisher=Geograph Project|accessdate=3 December 2013}} As ''North Street'', it passes the Burghley Centre{{cite web|url=http://homepages.which.net/~rex/bourne/burghleycentre.htm |title=The Burghley Centre, Bourne |publisher=Rex Needle |accessdate=11 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620051758/http://homepages.which.net/~rex/bourne/burghleycentre.htm |archivedate=20 June 2013 }} (shops), and Bourne Bus Station. At the two miniature roundabouts the name changes to North Road, which name it keeps until it reaches Morton. [[File:Robin Hood and Little John - geograph.org.uk - 275210.jpg|thumb|''Robin Hood and Little John'' at [[Aslackby]]]] Just outside Bourne, at {{coord|52.79975|-0.41525|display=inline|name=Junction of King Street & Mareham Lane Roman roads}}, the route of (Roman) King Street heads off across the fields to [[Stainfield]] and [[Ancaster, Lincolnshire|Ancaster]] but the A15 continues north along the line of another Roman road, [[Mareham Lane]]. It passes close to [[Dyke, Lincolnshire|Dyke]], and goes through [[Morton and Hanthorpe|Morton]] as ''Bourne Road'', passing the ''Lord Nelson''{{cite web|url=http://www.pub-explorer.com/olpg/the-lordnelson/morton/index.htm |title=The Lord Nelson, Morton |publisher=Pub-explorer.com |date=14 April 2003 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} pub. It becomes ''Folkingham Road''{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/312149and |title=Looking towards Bourne on the A15|work=OS grid TF0926|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=1 May 2013}} there is a right turn for [[Haconby]] and a junction with the B1177 (for [[Billingborough]]). Close by are [[Rippingale]] and [[Kirkby Underwood]]. Between Rippingale and [[Aslackby]] a wooded lay-by known locally as 'Turnpike Bar' marks the deviation from the line of the [[Roman roads in Britain|Roman Road]] [[Mareham Lane]]{{coord|52.84591|-0.3895|display=inline|format=dms|name=southern end of Mareham Lane Roman road}}. The A15 passes by [[Aslackby]] and the '' Robin Hood and Little John'',{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/275210 |title=Robin Hood and Little John|work=OS grid TF0830|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} and then through the middle of [[Folkingham]].{{cite web|title=A15, Folkingham|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2505160|publisher=Geograph project|accessdate=3 December 2013}} [[File:Approach to Holdingham Roundabout on the A15 - geograph.org.uk - 1073672.jpg|thumb|left|Sleaford Bypass looking north to Holdingham]] There is the [[Threekingham Bar]] roundabout{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/360104 |title=Osbournby Roundabout|work=OS grid TF0736|publisher=Geograph project |date=10 March 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} with the east-west [[A52 road|A52]], and it goes through [[Osbournby]], as ''London Road'' the primary school].{{cite web|url=http://www.osbournby.lincs.sch.uk |title=Osbournby Primary School |publisher=Osbournby.lincs.sch.uk | accessdate=11 May 2013}} It passes the ''Tally Ho Inn]''{{cite web|url=http://www.thetallyhoinn.com |title=Fine Pub Food in Sleaford, Lincolnshire |publisher=The Tally Ho Inn | accessdate=11 May 2013}}{{cite web|title=The Tally-Ho Inn|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2805324|publisher=Geograph project|accessdate=3 December 2013}} near [[Aswarby]], then there are left turns for [[Aunsby]] and [[Aswarby and Swarby|Swarby]]. [[Sleaford]] and Silk Willoughby]{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/360524 |title=Silk Willoughby - must be better than this?|work=OS grid TF0442|publisher=Geograph project |date=10 March 2013 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} were on the A15, which slowed traffic down as the traffic went across a [[level crossing]] and through Sleaford's shopping area. The £5.7 million bypass opened on 16 September 1993, by [[Douglas Hogg, 3rd Viscount Hailsham|Douglas Hogg]], where there is a roundabout with the A153 and B1517. The A15 crosses the railway{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/122470 |title=Road Bridge Over Railway|work=OS grid TF0545|publisher=Geograph project |date=15 February 2006 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} and [[River Slea]], and then leaves the bypass at the ''Holdingham Roundabout'' with the [[A17 road (Great Britain)|A17]] and B1518 (former route). [[File:Approach to Holdingham Roundabout on the B1518 - geograph.org.uk - 1136107.jpg|thumb|Approaching the Holdingham Roundabout from the former route]] As ''Lincoln Road'', it goes close to [[Leasingham]] meeting the B1209. There is a junction{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/384168 |title=for |publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} [[Cranwell]] with the B1429. It meets the B1191 (for [[Scopwick]]), B1202 (for [[Boothby Graffoe]] to the west and [[Metheringham]] to the east) next to the former [[RAF Coleby Grange]], and B1178 (for [[Harmston]]), where it passes [[Dunston Pillar]]. At [[Nocton]] Heath, it passes the ''Kitchen''{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/490205 |title=The Kitchen|work=OS grid TF0160|publisher=Geograph project |date=9 July 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} cafe.[http://www.thekitchenatnoctonheath.co.uk Untitled Document] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320212735/http://www.thekitchenatnoctonheath.co.uk/ |date=20 March 2012 }} On the route to Lincoln, it goes near to two RAF bases – [[RAF Digby]], which is used for communications rather than as a flying station, and across the end{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/419932 |title=A15 passes Waddington airfield|work=OS grid SK9964|publisher=Geograph project |date=1 May 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} of the runway of [[RAF Waddington]], which flies [[E-3 Sentry|AWACS]] and [[Hawker-Siddeley Nimrod|Nimrod]] aircraft. A parking place and cafe are provided for plane spotters on the eastern side of the road. [[File:On guard - geograph.org.uk - 687930.jpg|thumb|left|Vulcan XM607 by the side of the A15 at [[RAF Waddington]] which took part in [[Operation Black Buck]] ]] Next{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/687930 |title=On guard|work=OS grid SK9965|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} to the runway at Waddington is an old [[Avro Vulcan|Vulcan]], carrying the number of the plane that bombed [[Port Stanley]]. The A15 and [[Ermine Street]] meet at Bracebridge Heath, about {{convert|1000|m|yd|order=flip}} north of the traffic lights for [[Canwick]] {{coord|53.20207|-0.54558|display=inline|format=dms|name=A15 and Roman Ermine Street converge at Bracebridge Heath}}. ===Lincoln=== [[File:South Common - geograph.org.uk - 54273.jpg|thumb|left|South Common]] At [[Bracebridge Heath]], it passes the [[Total S.A.|Total]] ''Sleaford Road Service Station'', just before it passes the ''Blacksmiths Arms'', and meets the end of the [[A607 road|A607]] at [[traffic light]]s at ''The Bull''. Towards Lincoln, it meets the B1131 as ''London Road'', next to '' The Homestead''{{cite web|url=http://www.pub-explorer.com/lincs/pub/homestead.htm |title=on PubExplorer |publisher=Pub-explorer.com |accessdate=11 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313012738/http://www.pub-explorer.com/lincs/pub/homestead.htm |archivedate=13 March 2012 }} (former St John's Hospital). It is crossed by the [[Viking Way]] at the moment [[Lincoln Cathedral]] comes into full view. The road meets the A1434 ''[[Newark-on-Trent|Newark]] Road'' from [[North Hykeham]] at traffic lights after passing [[The Priory Academy LSST]] and a bridge over the former [[Great Northern Railway (Great Britain)|GNR]] Grantham-Lincoln railway, where it becomes ''St Catherine's Road'',{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/568993 |title=St.Catherines|work=OS grid SK9769|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} and passes{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/567595 |title=Site of the Eleanor Cross|work=OS grid SK9769|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} an [[Eleanor Cross]]. At a roundabout at the south end of (what becomes) Lincoln's ''[[High Street, Lincoln|High Street]]'', it exits to the right along ''South Park'', passing the HQ of [[Lincolnshire Fire and Rescue Service]], and meets the B1188 at traffic lights, where it heads left as ''Canwick Road''.{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/411652 |title=Canwick Road approaching Lincoln City Centre from the south|work=OS grid SK9770|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} [[File:The A15, Lincoln - geograph.org.uk - 690346.jpg|thumb|Looking south over Pelham Bridge]] At Pelham Bridge{{cite web|author=50 years of Pelham Bridge |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/lincolnshire/content/articles/2008/06/26/pelhambridge_50_feature.shtml |title=Lincolnshire - Places - 50 years of Pelham Bridge |publisher=BBC |date=26 June 2008 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} (which was opened by the [[Elizabeth II|Queen]] in 1958), it crosses the [[Peterborough to Lincoln Line|railway]], with the [[Lincoln Central railway station|railway station]] on the left, the junction with the start of the [[A57 road|A57]] and [[Ruston (engine builder)|Siemens]] (former [[Alstom]]) factory. It crosses the [[River Witham]], before heading up the hill on the north side of the [[Lincoln Cliff|Lincoln Gap]], and heading in the direction of the A158 as ''Lindum Road'' (for [[Skegness]]), where it is crossed by the [[Viking Way]] near [[Lincoln Minster School]]. As ''Wragby Road'', it passes [[Lincoln Christ's Hospital School]] on the left, then meets the B1308{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/52821 |title=Outer Circle Road, Lincoln|work=OS grid SK9972|publisher=Geograph project |date=13 September 2005 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} near the large Carlton Centre Retail Park. The ''Lincolnshire Poacher''{{cite web|url=http://www.lincolnshirepoacherpub.co.uk |title=Lincolnshire Poacher - Lincoln |publisher=Lincolnshirepoacherpub.co.uk |date=28 April 2013 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} is on the right hand side and there is a right turn for [[Cherry Willingham]] and [[Reepham, Lincolnshire|Reepham]]. Modern traffic routing has taken the road away from the route of [[Ermine Street]] as it passes through Lincoln. ===Lindsey=== [[File:Ermine Street - geograph.org.uk - 275160.jpg|thumb|left|North of Lincoln near Riseholme]] [[File:The A15, Barton-upon-Humber - geograph.org.uk - 696210.jpg|thumb|left|The Humber Bridge looking north]] [[File:RAF Scampton front the air.jpeg|thumb|right|The A15 at its 1950s curvature east of Ermine Street around RAF Scampton, seen in March 2016]] North of Lincoln, the A15 enters [[West Lindsey]], and meets the start of the A158 at a roundabout, then runs concurrently{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/275900 |title=A46 Lincoln Ring Road|work=OS grid SK9874|publisher=Geograph project |date=9 November 2006 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} with the [[A46 road|A46]] to the ''Riseholme'' roundabout, where it briefly re-enters the City of Lincoln, then follows{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/275160 |title=Ermine Street|work=OS grid SK9776|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} the [[Roman road]] [[Ermine Street]] past the [[Lincolnshire School of Agriculture|Riseholme College of Agriculture]] on the right, now part of the [[University of Lincoln]], and Lincolnshire Showground{{cite web|url=http://www.lincolnshireshowground.co.uk |title=Lincolnshire Events Centre | Lincolnshire Showground | Events Centre |publisher=Lincolnshire Showground |date=18 January 2013 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} to the left.{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/89223 |title=Entrance to Lincolnshire Showground from the A15|work=OS grid SK9777|publisher=Geograph project |date=10 December 2005 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} At the end of a {{convert|40|mph}} section is the ''Tillbridge Lane'' roundabout{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/89224 |title=Commercial Buildings at the A1500 A15 junction|work=OS grid SK9778|publisher=Geograph project |date=10 December 2005 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} with the A1500, for [[Gainsborough, Lincolnshire|Gainsborough]]. From here, it used to be straight, but with [[RAF Scampton]] becoming a base for [[V bomber]]s in the 1950s, the runway had to be extended and the road now has a curved diversion to the east. It passes the Scampton primary school{{cite web|url=http://www.pollyplatt.lincs.sch.uk |title=Home |publisher=Pollyplatt.lincs.sch.uk | accessdate=11 May 2013}} and continues{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/416347 |title=Ermine Street|work=OS grid SK9685|publisher=Geograph project |date=28 April 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} past a right turn to [[Normanby by Spital]], on its most straight section, also the parish boundary of many local villages. At the roundabout with the [[A631 road|A631]] at [[Caenby Corner]], there is the [[Total S.A.|Total]] ''Caenby Corner Garage'' just south of [[Spital-in-the-Street]]. Overtaking is difficult as the road, although straight, is undulating with unmarked dips and slow moving farm traffic. There are two right turns for [[Bishop Norton]] and [[Atterby]]. There is a right turn for [[Snitterby]] and a left turn for [[Blyborough]]. At the B1205 staggered crossroads{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/142584 |title=B1205 junction with the A15|work=OS grid SK9696|publisher=Geograph project |date=26 March 2006 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} (for [[Waddingham]] to the east, and [[Grayingham]] to the west), it enters [[North Lincolnshire]]. [[File:A15 near Scawby - geograph.org.uk - 234368.jpg|thumb|Looking north near Scawby]] [[File:Start of the M180 - geograph.org.uk - 849005.jpg|thumb|A15/[[M180 motorway|M180]]/[[A180 road (England)|A180]] Barnetby Top Interchange]] [[File:A15 exit to Barton-Upon-Humber - geograph.org.uk - 39932.jpg|thumb|Looking north to the A1077 intersection]] At the B1206 crossroads, the old route used to go through [[Hibaldstow]] and [[Brigg]], with the former road to [[Redbourne]] now a cycle route. It passes close to [[Kirton in Lindsey]], home of [[RAF Kirton in Lindsey]] much used in the [[Second World War]] as a [[Battle of Britain airfields|fighter airfield]] in [[No. 12 Group RAF|12 Group]], now home to the [[Trent Valley Gliding Club]]. [[Hibaldstow]] was a wartime fighter airfield{{cite web|url=http://www.wartimememories.co.uk/airfields/hibaldstow.html |title=The Wartime Memories Project - RAF Hibaldstow |publisher=Wartimememories.co.uk |accessdate=11 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206173253/http://www.wartimememories.co.uk/airfields/hibaldstow.html |archivedate=6 December 2013 }} as well, and this is now used as a base for parachuting and parachuting competitions by [[Target Skysports]]. The {{convert|5|mi|adj=on}} £7 million Brigg and Redbourne bypass{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/326757 |title=A15 north towards the M180|work=OS grid SK9698|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} was added in December 1989 which follows{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/583632 |title=Lay-by on the A15 west of Hibaldstow|work=OS grid SE9503|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} the old Ermine Street in [[North Lincolnshire]] further than previously, with a much flatter, wider and safer road. This section was the upgraded route of an unclassified road. It crosses the [[Sheffield to Lincoln Line|Sheffield to Cleethorpes railway line]] near the deserted village of [[Gainsthorpe]], passes{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/234368 |title=A15 near Scawby|work=OS grid SE9505|publisher=Geograph project |date=6 September 2006 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} near to [[Scawby]], and joining{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/327474 |title=M180 west towards junction 4|work=OS grid SE9606|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} the [[M180 motorway|M180]] at junction 4, near [[Scunthorpe]]. It abandons the Roman alignments at a short spur to the A18 at the,''Briggate Lodge Roundabout'' next to the Forest Pines{{cite web|url=http://www.qhotels.co.uk/hotels/forest-pines-near-brigg.aspx |title=Hotels in North Lincolnshire - Forest Pines Hotel & Golf Resort |publisher=QHotels | accessdate=11 May 2013}} golf club and hotel at [[Broughton, Lincolnshire|Broughton]]. Ermine Street continues north as the B1207, meeting the Humber near [[Winteringham]]. The route of the A15 now becomes part of the three-laned M180, which was opened on 2 September 1977. The A15 section along Ermine Street was planned to be opened at the same time, but it had to wait twelve years. The buildup of traffic to Grimsby prompted calls for the Brigg bypass for many years, but the [[Flixborough disaster|Flixborough explosion]] of 1974 made it more of an emergency. This section goes under the [[A18 road (Great Britain)|A18]], over the [[River Ancholme]], over the old route of the A15 (B1206) and over the [[South TransPennine|South Trans-Pennine]] railway. At junction 5, the A15 reforms at the dual-grade ''Barnetby Top Interchange'', which is crossed by the [[Viking Way]] and has an exit to [[Elsham, Lincolnshire|Elsham]]. It continues north as a dual carriageway which carries about as little traffic as the M180. The M180 drops to two lanes under this roundabout and continues to [[Grimsby]] and [[Immingham]] as the A180. The A15 towards the [[Humber Bridge]], goes directly across the runways of the former [[RAF Bomber Command]] airfield at [[RAF Elsham Wolds]] (where over 1000 of its aircrew were killed), which is now the Elsham Wolds{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/211562 |title=Elsham Wolds - Old Hangar|work=OS grid TA0413|publisher=Geograph project |date=30 July 2006 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} Industrial Estate. The former route of the A15, pre-1978, is now called B1206,{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/61208 |title=The old Barton to Brigg Turnpike road|work=OS grid TA0314|publisher=Geograph project |date=4 October 2005 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} and ends at [[New Holland, North Lincolnshire|New Holland]], where the A15 formerly connected with the [[PS Lincoln Castle|Humber Ferry]]. The £5.6 million {{convert|6|mi|adj=on}} [[Brigg]] Bypass to [[Barton-upon-Humber]] Bypass (up to where the B1218 crosses){{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/494323 |title=A15|work=OS grid TA0219|publisher=Geograph project |date=14 July 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} section opened in June 1978. The £2 million {{convert|1|mi|adj=on}} Barton-upon-Humber Bypass to Humber Bridge (A1077 interchange){{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/39932 |title=A15 exit to Barton-Upon-Humber|work=OS grid TA0220|publisher=Geograph project |date=19 August 2005 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} section opened in September 1978, although some maps show this being open before the southern section to the M180. When this whole section{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/51501 |title=A15|work=OS grid TA0218|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} opened to the GSJ with the A1077 (for [[South Ferriby]]) in 1978, there was no longer any access to the B1218. In the early 1990s, a new interchange{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/51498 |title=A15/B1206 turn-off|work=OS grid TA0316|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} was added with the B1206{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/393180 |title=The Road to Barton|work=OS grid TA0315|publisher=Geograph project |date=8 April 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} (the former A15), which is crossed{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/848959 |title=Crossing the A15|work=OS grid TA0216|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} by the Viking Way, which follows the road for over a mile. The section{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/24043 |title=Humber Bridge from South|work=OS grid TA0222|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} across the [[River Humber|Humber]] was opened on 17 July 1981, by the [[Elizabeth II|Queen]], and was the world's longest single-span bridge until 1997. The tolls{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/452359 |title=Humber Bridge toll plaza|work=OS grid TA0225|publisher=Geograph project | accessdate=11 May 2013}} are north of the bridge. It crosses{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/403031 |title=Rail and road|work=OS grid TA0225|publisher=Geograph project |date=16 April 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} the [[A63 road|A63]] and meets a roundabout with [[A164 road|A164]] (for [[Beverley]]) and A1105, then turns left along a short section{{cite web|url=https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/541875 |title=East or west?|work=OS grid TA0126|publisher=Geograph project |date=1 September 2007 |accessdate=11 May 2013}} of dual-carriageway (former A63) to end at the A63. ==See also== * [[Ermine Street]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Attached KML|display=inline,title}} * {{Commons category-inline|A15 road (England)}} * [http://www.sabre-roads.org.uk/roadlists/f99/15.shtml The Society for All British Road Enthusiasts' article on A15] {{UK primary routes 1}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1-0015}} [[Category:Lincoln, England]] [[Category:North Kesteven District]] [[Category:Borough of North Lincolnshire]] [[Category:Roads in Cambridgeshire]] [[Category:Roads in England]] [[Category:Roads in Lincolnshire]] [[Category:Roads in Yorkshire]] [[Category:Roads with a reversible lane]] [[Category:South Kesteven District]] [[Category:The Deepings]] [[Category:Transport in Huntingdonshire]] [[Category:Transport in Peterborough]] [[Category:Transport in the East Riding of Yorkshire]] [[Category:West Lindsey District]]

[[File:Abtwoudsebos delft 001.jpg|thumb|The view towards [[Tanthof]]]] The '''Abtswoudse Bos''' is man-made park and land art project, opened in 2000, of about 190 ha. It lies south of the [[Tanthof]] neighbourhood in [[Delft]], east of [[Schipluiden]] and north of [[Overschie]].
The Abtswoudse Bos is situated in a [[polder]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hofvandelfland.nl/node/437 | title=Het Abtswoudse bos|website=Hofvandelfland.nl| date=2014-12-16}}</ref> and has trees, bushes, footpaths, cycling roads, ditches, lakes, and small ponds.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://recreatie.middendelfland.net/gebieden/abtswoudsebos.htm | title=Abtswoudse Bos|website=Recreatie.middendelfland.net}}</ref> The area's waters contain many [[aquatic plants]], like reeds, underwater plants, and floating plants. The polder used to consists of meadows.
== Mother Earth == In the centre of the park lies '''Moeder Aarde''' (Dutch for Mother Earth). It consists of an artificial hill of about 200 meter wide, 170 meter long and 5 meter high, resembling a human figure. Around this hill is a meadow with planted ashes. In the center of Mother Earth is a circular pond. Bushes with berries have been planted on the arms and legs. The knees, hands, and feet have stayed open The footpaths on the hill are meant to resemble blood veins.
<gallery> File:Abtwoudsebos delft 002.jpg|Lake of Mother Earth File:Abtwoudsebos delft 003.jpg|Man-planted ashes File:Abtwoudsebos delft 004.jpg|Wetlands File:Wetlands_in_Abtswoudse_Bos,_Delft.jpg|Mother Earth seen from a distance </gallery>

{{hatnote|This article is about the sociopolitical concept encompassing developed nations where English is the primary language. For other nations where English is an official language or widely spoken, see [[English-speaking world]] or [[List of countries where English is an official language]].}} {{use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} The '''Anglosphere''' is the set of [[English-speaking world|English-speaking]] nations that share common cultural and historical roots with the [[British Isles]],{{cite web|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/anglosphere|title=Anglosphere definition and meaning – Collins English Dictionary|website=www.collinsdictionary.com}}{{cite web|url=https://ipolitics.ca/2017/02/24/canzuk-conservatives-and-canada-marching-backward-to-empire/|title=CANZUK, Conservatives and Canada: Marching backward to empire – iPolitics|date=24 February 2017|publisher=}} and which today maintain close cultural, political, diplomatic and military cooperation. While the nations included in different sources vary, the Anglosphere is usually not considered to include all countries where English is an official language, although the nations that are commonly included were all once part of the [[British Empire]].{{cite web|url=https://www.britac.ac.uk/events/anglosphere-and-its-others-english-speaking-peoples-changing-world-order|title=The Anglosphere and its Others: The 'English-speaking Peoples' in a Changing World Order – British Academy|website=British Academy}} Most definitions include the five main countries, namely [[Australia]], [[Canada]], [[New Zealand]], the [[United Kingdom]], and the [[United States]]. The term can also cover the [[Republic of Ireland]]{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/nov/03/the-guardian-view-on-languages-and-the-british-brexit-and-an-anglosphere-prison|title=The Guardian view on languages and the British: Brexit and an Anglosphere prison – Editorial|first=|last=Editorial|date=3 November 2017|website=the Guardian}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/f30b22d0-703f-11e4-bc6a-00144feabdc0|title=Which way is Ireland going?|website=Financial Times}} and English-speaking [[Caribbean]] countries such as [[The Bahamas]], [[Barbados]], and [[Jamaica]].{{sfn|Lloyd|2000}} == Definitions and variable geometry == [[File:Anglosphere Geometry.svg|thumb|400px|Variable geometry of the Anglosphere, according to James Bennett (''The Anglosphere Challenge'')]] The term ''Anglosphere'' was first coined, but not explicitly defined, by the science fiction writer [[Neal Stephenson]] in his book ''[[The Diamond Age]]'', published in 1995. John Lloyd adopted the term in 2000 and defined it as including the United States and the United Kingdom along with English-speaking Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Ireland, South Africa and the [[British West Indies]].{{sfn|Lloyd|2000}} The [[Webster's Dictionary|Merriam-Webster]] dictionary defines the Anglosphere as "the countries of the world in which the English language and cultural values predominate".{{sfn|Merriam-Webster Staff|2010|loc=''Anglosphere''}}{{efn|"the group of countries where [[English language|English]] is the main native language"({{ShorterOxfordEnglishDictionary}}).}} [[File:Commonwealth and Anglosphere.svg|thumb|400px|{{Color box|#000080|border=darkgray}} [[Commonwealth Realms]] where Elizabeth II remains head of state
{{Color box|#0000FF|border=darkgray}} [[Commonwealth of Nations]] members (all except Rwanda and Mozambique formerly parts of the British Empire)
{{Color box|#00ccff|border=darkgray}} countries that were formerly part of the British Empire but currently not a member of the Commonwealth
{{Color box|#ffcc00|border=darkgray}} countries formerly under United States rule or influence that have adopted English as one of their main languages]] The five main countries in the Anglosphere (the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom) maintain a close affinity of cultural, diplomatic and military links with one another. All are aligned under such programs as: *The [[UKUSA Agreement]] (signals intelligence), *[[Five Eyes]] (intelligence), *[[Combined Communications Electronics Board]] (communications electronics), *[[The Technical Cooperation Program]] (technology and science), *[[Air and Space Interoperability Council]] (air forces), *[[AUSCANNZUKUS]] (navies) and *[[ABCA Armies]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wordspy.com/words/Anglosphere.asp|title=Anglosphere – Word Spy|publisher=Word Spy}}{{sfn|Bennett|2004|p=80}}{{sfn|Lloyd|2000}}{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/padm.12198/abstract|title=Transgovernmental Policy Networks in the Anglosphere|first=Tim|last=Legrand|date=1 December 2015|publisher=|journal=Public Administration|volume=93|issue=4|pages=973–991|via=Wiley Online Library|doi=10.1111/padm.12198}}{{cite journal |url=https://doi.org/10.1080/01442872.2016.1188912 |title=Elite, exclusive and elusive: transgovernmental policy networks and iterative policy transfer in the Anglosphere |first=Tim|last=Legrand |date= 22 June 2016 |publisher= |journal=Policy Studies |volume=37|issue=5|pages=440–455 |via=Taylor & Francis Online |doi=10.1080/01442872.2016.1188912}} Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom retain [[Elizabeth II]] as [[head of state]], form part of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] and use of the [[Westminster system|Westminster parliamentary system]] of government. In the wake of the [[Brexit|United Kingdom's decision to leave the European Union]] as a result of a [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|referendum held in 2016]], there has been mounting political and popular support for a loose free travel and common market area to be formed between them known as [[CANZUK]].{{cite web|url=https://www.thercs.org/assets/Press-Releases/UK-polling-release-embargoed-13.03.16-1.pdf|title=UK public strongly backs freedom to live and work in Australia, Canada, and New Zealand|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.canzukinternational.com/2017/04/significant-support-for-canzuk-free.html|title=Survey Reveals Support For CANZUK Free Movement|website=CANZUK International}} Below is a table comparing the five main countries of the Anglosphere. Eyes (FV) ! {{nts|459815862}} ! {{nts|26428470}} ! $26,799.567 !$58,283 !$129,269 !$707,309 |- !FV as % of World !6.0% !17.7% !19.9% !329.6% !40.8% !41.6% |} ==Public relations== Public opinion research has found that people in the United States, United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and New Zealand consistently rank each other's countries as their country's most important allies in the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/02/03/upshot/which-country-do-americans-like-most-for-republicans-its-australia.html|title=Which Country Is America’s Strongest Ally? For Republicans, It’s Australia|first=Josh|last=Katz|date=3 February 2017|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}{{cite web|url=https://yougov.co.uk/news/2015/10/14/who-do-british-regard-allies/|title=YouGov – Who do the British regard as allies?|website=YouGov: What the world thinks}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ipsos.com/en-ca/news-polls/while-60-canadians-consider-usa-canadas-closest-friend-and-ally-only-18-americans-name-canada-same|title=While 60% of Canadians Consider U.S.A. Canada's Closest Friend and Ally, Only 18% of Americans Name Canada As Same – 56% Instead Name Britain|publisher=}} Relations have traditionally been warm between Anglosphere countries, with bilateral partnerships such as those between [[Australia–New Zealand relations|Australia and New Zealand]], [[United States–Canada relations|the US and Canada]] and [[United States–United Kingdom relations|the US and UK]] constituting among the most successful partnerships in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.australianreview.net/journal/v2/n1/goff.pdf|title='The Trans-Tasman Relationship: A New Zealand Perspective'|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.realclearworld.com/articles/2016/03/09/us_and_canada_the_worlds_most_successful_bilateral_relationship_111753.html|title=U.S. and Canada: The World's Most Successful Bilateral Relationship – RealClearWorld|publisher=}}{{cite journal|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14794012.2012.678119?src=recsys&journalCode=rjts20|title=‘Global Security: US–UK relations’: lessons for the special relationship?|first=Steve|last=Marsh|date=1 June 2012|publisher=|journal=Journal of Transatlantic Studies|volume=10|issue=2|pages=182–199|doi=10.1080/14794012.2012.678119}} Favourability ratings tend to be overwhelmingly positive between countries within a subset of the Anglosphere known as [[CANZUK]] (consisting of Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom),{{cite web|url=https://globescan.com/sharp-drop-in-world-views-of-us-uk-global-poll/|title=Sharp Drop in World Views of US, UK: Global Poll – GlobeScan|date=4 July 2017|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.britishcouncil.org/sites/default/files/from_the_outside_in.pdf|title=From the Outside In: G20 views of the UK before and after the EU referendum'|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/home/new-zealand/2017/06/poll-who-s-new-zealand-s-best-friend.html|title=Poll: Who's New Zealand's best friend?|date=22 June 2017|publisher=|via=www.newshub.co.nz}}{{cite web|url=https://www.lowyinstitute.org/publications/2018-lowy-institute-poll|title=Poll|year=2018 |publisher=Lowy Institute }} whose members form part of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] and retain Elizabeth II as head of state. While the [[Brexit|United Kingdom's decision to leave the European Union]] [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|in 2016]] has had little impact on its favourability ratings with other members of the Anglosphere, there has been a marked drop in the United States favourability ratings with other Anglosphere nations since [[United States presidential election, 2016|the election]] of [[Donald Trump]] as the [[List of Presidents of the United States|45th]] [[President of the United States]] in 2016.{{cite web|last=Marcin|first=Tim|url=http://www.newsweek.com/canadas-opinion-america-hits-low-under-trump-poll-606315|title=Canada's Opinion of America Hits All-Time Low Under Trump|date=9 May 2017|publisher=Newsweek}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pewglobal.org/2017/06/26/u-s-image-suffers-as-publics-around-world-question-trumps-leadership/|title=U.S. Image Suffers as Publics Around World Question Trump’s Leadership|date=26 June 2017|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pewglobal.org/database/indicator/1/survey/all/|title=Global Indicators Database|date=22 April 2010|publisher=}} In 2017, the United States had negative favourability ratings with the CANZUK countries. ==Proponents== The American businessman [[James C. Bennett]],{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/oct/28/uselections2004.usa4|title=Explaining the 'Anglosphere'|first=Glenn|last=Reynolds|date=28 October 2004|website=the Guardian}} a proponent of the idea that there is something special about the cultural and legal traditions of English-speaking nations, writes in his 2004 book ''The Anglosphere Challenge'': {{quote|The Anglosphere, as a network civilization without a corresponding political form, has necessarily imprecise boundaries. Geographically, the densest nodes of the Anglosphere are found in the United States and the United Kingdom. English-speaking Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Ireland and English-speaking South Africa (who constitute a very small minority in that country) are also significant populations. The English-speaking Caribbean, English-speaking [[Oceania]] and the English-speaking educated populations in Africa and India constitute other important nodes.|James C. Bennett.{{sfn|Bennett|2004||p=80}}}} Bennett argues that there are two challenges confronting his concept of the Anglosphere. The first is finding ways to cope with rapid technological advancement and the second is the geopolitical challenges created by what he assumes will be an increasing gap between anglophone prosperity and economic struggles elsewhere.{{harvnb|Bennett|2004|loc=}}{{Page needed|date=August 2010}} British historian [[Andrew Roberts (historian)|Andrew Roberts]] claims that the Anglosphere has been central in the [[First World War]], [[Second World War]] and [[Cold War]]. He goes on to contend that anglophone unity is necessary for the defeat of [[Islamism]].{{harvnb|Roberts|2006|loc=}}{{Page needed|date=August 2010}} According to a 2003 profile in ''[[The Guardian]]'', historian [[Robert Conquest]] favoured a British withdrawal from the [[European Union]] in favour of creating "a much looser association of English-speaking nations, known as the 'Anglosphere'".{{sfn|Brown|2003}}{{cite web|url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/brexit/2015/12/10/anglosphere-is-the-other-side-of-the-eurosceptic-coin-a-conception-of-britains-identity-and-place-in-the-world/|title=The power of the Anglosphere in Eurosceptical thought|date=10 December 2015|publisher=}} New Zealand historian [[James Belich (historian)|James Belich]] connected patterns of growth in the industrialisation of the United States and the United Kingdom with former [[Dominion]]s of the [[British Empire]];{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} New Zealand, Australia, Canada and South Africa, and more loosely to growth in former UK constituent country Ireland, as well as British-allied [[Argentina]], during the 19th and early to mid-20th century, in his book ''Replenishing the Earth''. He used the term "Anglo-World" to refer to the US, UK and former Dominions, arguing that the experience and present reality of former British colonies like [[India]], [[Kenya]], and [[Jamaica]] differ in substantial and important ways from this core group of countries. ==Criticisms== In 2000, [[Michael Ignatieff]] wrote in an exchange with [[Robert Conquest]], published by the ''[[New York Review of Books]]'', that the term neglects the evolution of fundamental legal and cultural differences between the US and the UK, and the ways in which UK and European norms have been drawn closer together during Britain's membership in the EU through regulatory harmonisation. Of Conquest's view of the Anglosphere, Ignatieff writes: "He seems to believe that Britain should either [[Brexit|withdraw from Europe]] or refuse all further measures of cooperation, which would jeopardize Europe's real achievements. He wants Britain to throw in its lot with a union of English-speaking peoples, and I believe this to be a romantic illusion".{{sfn|Conquest|Reply by Ignatieff|2000}} In 2016, [[Nick Cohen]] wrote in an article titled "It’s a Eurosceptic fantasy that the ‘Anglosphere’ wants Brexit" for ''[[The Spectator]]''’s Coffee House blog: "‘Anglosphere’ is just the right's [[Political correctness|PC]] replacement for what we used to call in blunter times ‘the white Commonwealth’."{{cite web|url=https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2016/04/its-a-eurosceptic-fantasy-that-the-anglosphere-wants-brexit/|title=It’s a Eurosceptic fantasy that the ‘Anglosphere’ wants Brexit - Coffee House|date=12 April 2016|publisher=}} He repeated this criticism in another article for ''[[The Guardian]]'' in 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jul/14/brexit-britain-out-of-options-humiliation-painful|title=Brexit Britain is out of options. Our humiliation is painful to watch - Nick Cohen|first=Nick|last=Cohen|date=14 July 2018|website=the Guardian}} Similar criticism was presented by other critics such as Canadian academic Srđan Vučetić.{{cite web|url=https://ipolitics.ca/2017/02/24/canzuk-conservatives-and-canada-marching-backward-to-empire/|title=CANZUK, Conservatives and Canada: Marching backward to empire - iPolitics|date=24 February 2017|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.opencanada.org/features/canada-and-anglo-world-where-do-we-stand/|title=Canada and the Anglo World – where do we stand?|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1160613/jsp/opinion/story_90833.jsp|title=Speaking in tongues|publisher=}} In 2018, amidst the aftermath of the [[Brexit referendum]], two British professors of public policy [[Michael Kenny (political scientist)|Michael Kenny]] and Nick Pearce published a critical scholarly monograph titled ''Shadows of Empire: The Anglosphere in British Politics'' ({{ISBN|978-1509516612}}). In one of a series of accompanying opinion pieces, they questioned:{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/13/opinion/donald-trump-uk-visit-anglosphere-brexit.html|title=Opinion – Britain, Time to Let Go of the ‘Anglosphere’|publisher=}} {{quote|The tragedy of the different national orientations that have emerged in British politics after empire—whether pro-European, Anglo-American, Anglospheric or some combination of these—is that none of them has yet been the compelling, coherent and popular answer to the country’s most important question: How should Britain find its way in the wider, modern world?}} They stated in another article:{{cite web|url=http://ukandeu.ac.uk/in-the-shadows-of-empire-how-the-anglosphere-dream-lives-on/|title=In the shadows of empire: how the Anglosphere dream lives on – UK in a changing Europe|date=11 May 2018|publisher=}} {{quote|Meanwhile, the other core English-speaking countries to which the Anglosphere refers, show no serious inclination to join the UK in forging new political and economic alliances. They will, most likely, continue to work within existing regional and international institutions and remain indifferent to – or simply perplexed by – calls for some kind of formalised Anglosphere alliance.}} ==See also== {{Wikipedia books|Anglosphere}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[British diaspora in Africa]] * [[English-speaking world]] * [[Border Five]], [[Five Nations Passport Group]], [[Five Country Conference]] * [[Five Power Defence Arrangements]] * ''[[History of the English Speaking Peoples]]'' (Winston Churchill) *[[JUSCANZ]], [[CANZUK]] * [[List of countries by English-speaking population]] * [[List of countries where English is an official language]] * [[Francosphere]] (French), [[Hispanosphere]] (Spanish), [[Lusosphere]] (Portuguese) {{div col end}} {{portal bar|Commonwealth realms|British Empire}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} * {{Cite news|ref=harv |last=Bell|first=Duncan|date=19 January 2017 |url=https://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/magazine/anglosphere-old-dream-brexit-role-in-the-world |title=The Anglosphere: new enthusiasm for an old dream|publisher=Prospect}} *Luca Bellocchio, ''Anglosfera. Forma e forza del nuovo Pan-Anglismo'', Genova, Il Melangolo, 2006 {{ISBN|978-88-7018-601-7}} *{{Cite book|ref=harv |last=Bennett |first=James C. |year=2004 |title=The anglosphere challenge: why the English-speaking nations will lead the way in the twenty-first century |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=_SaenLfzEAUC&pg=PA80 80] |isbn=0742533328}} *{{Cite news|ref=harv |last=Brown |first=Andrew |date=15 February 2003 |url=http://books.guardian.co.uk/poetry/features/0,12887,902797,00.html |title=Scourge and poet|publisher=The Guardian}} *{{cite journal|ref=harv |last=Conquest |first=Robert |last2=Reply by Ignatieff |first2=Michael |date=23 March 2000 |url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/104 |title=The 'Anglosphere' |journal=The New York Review of Books |accessdate=2007-07-24}} *{{cite news|last=Hannan|first=Daniel|date=2 March 2014|title=The Anglosphere is alive and well, but I wonder whether it needs a better name|newspaper=[[Daily Telegraph]]|url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/danielhannan/100261784/the-anglosphere-is-alive-and-well-but-i-wonder-whether-it-needs-a-better-name/|access-date=12 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407201815/http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/danielhannan/100261784/the-anglosphere-is-alive-and-well-but-i-wonder-whether-it-needs-a-better-name/|archive-date=7 April 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} *{{cite journal |ref=harv |last1=Kenny|first1=Michael |last2=Pearce|first2=Nick |year=2015 |title=The rise of the Anglosphere: how the right dreamed up a new conservative world order|journal=New Statesman |url=https://www.newstatesman.com/politics/2015/02/rise-anglosphere-how-right-dreamed-new-conservative-world-order |accessdate=2018-05-23}} *{{cite journal |ref=harv |last=Lloyd |first=John |year=2000 |title=The Anglosphere Project |journal=New Statesman |url=https://www.newstatesman.com/node/193400 |accessdate=30 November 2012}} *{{Cite book|ref=harv |last=Merriam-Webster Staff |year=2010 |chapterurl=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/anglosphere |chapter=Anglosphere |title=Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary |accessdate=5 August 2010}} *{{Cite book|ref=harv |last=Roberts |first=Andrew |authorlink=Andrew Roberts (historian) |year=2006 |title=A History of the English-Speaking Peoples Since 1900 |publisher=Weidenfeld & Nicolson |isbn=0297850768}} *{{Cite book|ref=harv |last=Kenny |first=Michael |last2=Pearce |first2=Nick |year=2018 |title=Shadows of Empire: The Anglosphere in British Politics |publisher=Polity |isbn=978-1-509-51660-5| url=http://politybooks.com/bookdetail/?isbn=9781509516605}} *{{cite book |last=Vucetic |first=Srdjan |year=2011 |title=The Anglosphere: A Genealogy of a Racialized Identity in International Relations |publisher=Stanford University Press |isbn=978-0-8047-7224-2}} * ==External links== {{Wiktionary|anglosphere}} * [http://anglosphere.org.uk Conservative Friends of the Anglosphere] *[https://www.webcitation.org/6ND58sVaR?url=http://explorersfoundation.org/archive/anglosphere_primer.pdf James C. Bennett (2002) An Anglosphere Primer], presented to the [[Foreign Policy Research Institute]] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09j6qz8 BBC Radio 4: Archive on 4: Return of the Anglosphere] {{English official language clickable map}} [[Category:Anglosphere| ]] [[Category:British Empire]] [[Category:Commonwealth of Nations]] [[Category:Historical regions]]

revision.text:
A '''Bioeffector''' is a viable [[microorganism]] or active natural compound which directly or indirectly affects plant performance ([[Biofertilizer]]), and thus has the potential to reduce [[fertilizer]] and [[pesticide]] use in crop production.<ref>[http://dpg.phytomedizin.org/fileadmin/tagungen/03_PPPHE/Doku/2014/MinutesPPPHE2014.pdf Minutes of the 6th International Symposium Plant Protection and Plant Health in Europe, May 2014 Braunschweig, Germany]</ref>
== Types == Bioeffectors have a direct or indirect effect on plant performance by influencing the functional implementation or activation of biological mechanisms, particularly those interfering with soil-plant-microbe interactions.<ref>V. Römheld, G. Neumann (2006): ''The Rhizosphere: Contributions of the soil-root interface to sustainable soil systems''. In: N. Uphoff, N., N. A. S. Ball et al. (Hg.), ''Biological Approaches to Sustainable Soil Systems'', S. 92–107, CRC-Press, Oxford, UK.</ref> In contrast to conventional fertilizers and pesticides, the effectiveness of bioeffectors is not based on a substantial direct input of mineral plant nutrients, either in inorganic or organic forms.
*Products in use are: ** Microbial residues, ** Composting and fermentation products, ** Plant and algae extracts *Bioeffector-preparations (''bio-agents'') as ready-formulated products are applied: ** with the purpose of stimulating plant growth (bio-stimulants), ** to improve plant nutrient acquisition (bio-fertilizers), ** to protect plants from [[pathogens]] and [[Pest (organism)|pests]] ([[Biological pest control|bio-control agents]]) ** or generally to advance cropping efficiency; they can contain one or more bio-effectors along with other substances”<ref>Bakonyi N., Donath S., Weinmann M., Neumann G., [[Torsten Müller (agroscientist)|Müller T.]], [[Volker Roemheld|Römheld V.]] (2008): Assessing commercial bio-fertilisers for improved phoshorus availability. Use of rapid screening tests. Jahrestagung der Deutschen Gesellschaft für Pflanzenernährung 2008</ref> *Well established bioeffectors with documented positive results in the field level are: ** [[Rhizobia]] strains for soil or seed inoculation as a prerequisite for symbiotic N2-fixation when establishing new legume species or varieties. ** positive effects of [[mycorrhiza]] inoculation for soils with a (temporarily) low potential for natural root mycorrhization. ** sufficient mycorrhization enhances nutrient (P) and water uptake and increases resistance to pathogenic fungi. *Further mechanisms for the positive impact of bioeffectors on plant growth have postulated, promising a high potential for resource preservation due to reduction of fertiliser and pesticide use: ** Active nutrient mobilisation by exudation of acids and carboxylates (e.g. P-mobilisation), ** exudation of micro-nutrient mobilising siderophores/chelates (e.g. Fe<sup>3+</sup>), ** reduction of trace elements from less soluble oxidised to highly soluble reduced forms (e.g. Fe<sup>3+</sup> to Fe<sup>2+</sup>, Mn<sup>4+</sup> to Mn<sup>2+</sup>), ** associative/non-symbiotic N<sub>2</sub>-fixation, protective antagonism to plant pathogens, ** enhancement of mycorrhizal infection and growth, and stimulating hormonal effects.
== Research and Public Dissemination == Under the Acronym ''Biofector'' the European Union supports the Research of Bioeffectors under the leadership of the [[University of Hohenheim]] (Coordinator [[Guenter Neumann (agricultural scientist)|Guenter Neumann]]). The results of the project will be evaluated by the members of the [[Association Biostimulants in Agriculture]] (ABISTA) and provided agriculture for use and EU institutions for the legislative and registration procedures.<ref>[http://www.biostimulants.info/ Webpage Biostimulants Association]</ref>
Other Biostimulants Organisations are [[European Biostimulant Industry Council]], [[International Biocontrol Manufacturers' Association]] and [[Annual Biocontrol Industry Meeting]].
== External links == * [http://www.biofector.org Webpage Biofector] * [http://www.biofector-database.eu/en/biofectors-homepage.html Biofector Database] * [http://www.biostimulants.info/ Webpage Association Biostimulants in Agriculture] * [http://biofector.af.czu.cz Webpage Biofector CULS Prague] * [http://www.raupp.biz Webpage Madora Bioeffectors] * [https://www.uni-hohenheim.de/1597.html?typo3state=projects&lsfid=1672 Webpage Biofector University of Hohenheim]
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2016}} [[File:Санаторий Орджоникидзе (г.Сочи) 01.jpg|thumb|Sochi]] [[Sochi]], is a city in Krasnodar Krai, Russia, located on the Black Sea coast has a [[humid subtropical climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification]] ''Cfa''), with warm rainy winter and sunny warm summer.
The territory of Sochi contains many [[microclimate]]s, the daytime temperatures can vary as much as 10 °C between coastal areas in [[Adlersky City District|Adler]] and [[Lazarevsky City District|Lazarevsky]] and 20 °C - [[Krasnaya Polyana, Sochi, Krasnodar Krai|Krasnaya Polyana]].
== Temperature ==
=== General === {| class="infobox bordered" style="text-align:center" |- !Yearly max temp !Yearly mean temp !Yearly min temp |- class="mergedrow" |{{convert|18.4|°C|°F|abbr=on}} |{{convert|14.2|°C|°F|abbr=on}} |{{convert|11.1|°C|°F|abbr=on}} |} Its average annual temperature is {{convert|18.4|°C|°F|abbr=on}} during the day and {{convert|11.1|°C|°F|abbr=on}} at night. In the coldest month – February, typically the temperature ranges from {{convert|5|to|15|C|F}} during the day and {{convert|2|to|10|C|F}} at night. In the warmest month – August, the typically temperature ranges from {{convert|25|to|30|C|F}} during the day and about {{convert|20|°C|°F|abbr=on}} at night. Large fluctuations in temperature are rare. The highest temperature recorded in Sochi was {{convert|38.4|°C|°F|abbr=on}} on July 30, 2000. The lowest temperature was {{convert|-13.4|°C|°F|abbr=on}} on January 25, 1892 and {{convert|-7.3|°C|°F|abbr=on}} on January 4, 2016 since 2001.
=== Seasonal climate === [[File:Plastunskaya interchange.JPG|200px|thumb|right|Winter in Sochi]]
==== Winter ==== Winters in Sochi are mild. January and February are the coldest months, with average temperatures around {{convert|10|°C|°F|abbr=on}} during the day and {{convert|3|°C|°F|abbr=on}} at night.
[[File:Bytkha Sochi.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Summer in Sochi]]
==== Summer ==== Generally the summer season lasts about six months, from May to October. July and August are the warmest months, with average temperatures around {{convert|27|-|28|C|F}} during the day and {{convert|20|°C|°F|abbr=on}} at night. In June and September the average temperature is around {{convert|25|°C|°F|abbr=on}} during the day and {{convert|15|°C|°F|abbr=on}} at night, and in May and October the average temperature is around {{convert|20|°C|°F|abbr=on}} during the day and {{convert|12|°C|°F|abbr=on}} at night.

{{For|the community in the U.S. state of Texas|Close City, Texas}} [[File:Seversk checkpoint.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.25|Central entry checkpoint to the closed city of [[Seversk]], Tomsk Oblast, Russia]]
A '''closed city''' or '''closed town''' is a settlement where travel or residency restrictions are applied so that specific authorization is required to visit or remain overnight. They may be sensitive military establishments or secret research installations which require much more space or freedom than is available in a conventional [[military base]]. There may also be a wider variety of permanent residents including close family members of workers or trusted traders who are not directly connected with its [[Clandestine operation|clandestine]] purposes.
Many closed cities existed in the [[Soviet Union]]. After 1991, a number of them still existed in the [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] countries, especially [[Russia]]. In modern Russia, such places are officially known as "closed administrative-territorial formations" ({{lang|ru|закрытые административно-территориальные образования}}, ''zakrytye administrativno-territorial'nye obrazovaniya'', or {{lang|ru|ЗАТО}} ''ZATO'' for short).
==Structure and operations== [[File:Checkpoint in closed city Zheleznogorsk, Krasnoyarsk Krai.jpg|thumb|A checkpoint in the closed city of [[Zheleznogorsk, Krasnoyarsk Krai|Zheleznogorsk]], in [[Krasnoyarsk Krai]], [[Russia]]]]
Sometimes closed cities may only be represented on [[Classified information|classified]] maps which are not available to the general public. In some cases there may be no road signs or directions to closed cities, and they are usually omitted from railroad time tables and bus routes.
Sometimes closed cities may be indicated obliquely as a nearby insignificant village, with the name of the stop serving the closed city made equivocal or misleading. For mail delivery, a closed city is usually named as the nearest large city and a special [[postcode]] e.g. Arzamas‑16, Chelyabinsk‑65. The actual settlement can be rather distant from its namesakes; for instance, [[Sarov]], designated Arzamas-16, is in the federal republic of [[Mordovia]], whereas [[Arzamas]] is in the [[Nizhny Novgorod Oblast]] (roughly {{convert|75|km}} away). People not living in a closed city were subject to document checks and [[security checkpoint]]s, and explicit permission was required for them to visit.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://photo-escape.ru/photo/backups/sarov-border/|title=City border|work=Photoarchives|publisher=FOTOESCAPE|accessdate =2013-03-16}}</ref> To relocate to a closed city, one would need security clearance by the organization running it, such as the [[KGB]] in Soviet closed cities.
Closed cities were sometimes guarded by a security perimeter with [[barbed wire]] and [[Watchtower|towers]]. The very fact of such a city's existence was often classified, and residents were expected not to divulge their place of residence to outsiders. This lack of freedom was often compensated by better housing conditions and a better choice of goods in retail trade than elsewhere in the country. Also, in the Soviet Union, people working with classified information received a [[Bonus payment|salary bonus]].
==Soviet Union closed cities== [[File:Map of Russia - Oblasts with Atomgrads.svg|thumb|300px|Map indicating federal subjects containing closed cities used for nuclear research and development]]
Closed cities were established in the [[Soviet Union]] from the late 1940s onwards under the euphemistic name of "post boxes", referring to the practice of addressing post to them via mail boxes in other cities. They fell into two distinct categories.
# The first category comprised relatively small communities with sensitive military, industrial, or scientific facilities, such as arms plants or [[nuclear research]] sites.<ref name="globalsecurity">[http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/russia/secret-cities.htm "Secret Cities".] [http://www.globalsecurity.org GlobalSecurity.org]. Accessed August 2011.</ref> Examples are the modern towns of [[Ozyorsk, Chelyabinsk Oblast|Ozyorsk]] ([[Chelyabinsk]]-65) with a [[plutonium]] production plant, and [[Sillamäe]], the site of a [[uranium enrichment]] facility. Even Soviet [[citizen]]s were not allowed access to these places without proper authorization. In addition to this, some bigger cities were closed for unauthorized access to foreigners, while they were freely accessible to Soviet citizens. These included cities like [[Perm]], a center for Soviet [[tank]] production, and [[Vladivostok]], the headquarters and primary base of the [[Soviet Pacific Fleet]]. # The second category consisted of border cities (and some whole border areas, such as the [[Kaliningrad Oblast]], [[Saaremaa]], and [[Hiiumaa]]) which were closed for security purposes. Comparable closed areas existed elsewhere in the [[Eastern bloc]]; a substantial area along the [[inner German border]] and the border between [[West Germany]] and [[Czechoslovakia]] was placed under similar restrictions (although by the 1970s foreigners could cross the latter by train). Citizens were required to have special permits to enter such areas.
The locations of the first category of the closed cities were chosen for their geographical characteristics. They were often established in remote places situated deep in the [[Urals]] and [[Siberia]], out of reach of enemy bombers. They were built close to rivers and lakes which were used to provide the large amounts of water needed for heavy industry and nuclear technology. Existing civilian settlements in the vicinity were often used as sources of construction labour. Although the closure of cities originated as a strictly temporary measure which was to be normalized under more favorable conditions, in practice the closed cities took on a life of their own and became a notable institutional feature of the Soviet system.<ref>Victor Zaslavsky, "Ethnic group divided: social stratification and nationality policy in the Soviet Union", p. 224, in Peter Joseph Potichnyj, ''The Soviet Union: Party and Society'', Cambridge University Press, 1988. {{ISBN|0-521-34460-3}}.</ref>
Movement to and from closed areas was tightly controlled. Foreigners were prohibited from entering them and local citizens were under stringent restrictions. They had to have special permission to travel there or leave, and anyone seeking residency was required to undergo vetting by the [[NKVD]] and its successor agencies. Access to some closed cities was physically enforced by surrounding them with [[barbed wire]] fences monitored by armed guards.
===The "box"=== "Box" was the unofficial name of a secret Soviet facility much like the closed city, but smaller, usually the size of a [[factory]]. The "box" name was usually classified, as were the activities there. Incoming [[mail]] was addressed to "mailbox #XXXX", thus the name of "box". Most Soviet design bureaus for [[weapon]]s, [[aircraft]], space, [[military]] [[electronics]], etc. were "boxes".{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}
==Closed cities in post-Soviet states== ===Russia=== [[File:Severomorsk (5145531991).jpg|thumb|A view of [[Severomorsk]], Murmansk Oblast, Russia]]
Russia has the largest number of closed cities. The policy of closing cities underwent major changes in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Some cities, such as [[Perm]], were opened well before the fall of the Soviet Union; others, such as [[Kaliningrad]] and [[Vladivostok]], remained closed until as late as 1992. The adoption of a new constitution for the Russian Federation in 1993 prompted significant reforms to the status of closed cities, which were renamed "closed administrative-territorial formations" (or ZATO, after the Russian acronym). [[Subdivisions of Russia#Municipal divisions|Municipally]] all such entities have a status of urban [[okrug]]s, as mandated by the federal law.
There are currently 44 publicly acknowledged closed cities in Russia with a total population of about 1.5 million people. 75% are administered by the [[Defence Ministry of the Russian Federation|Russian Ministry of Defense]], with the rest being administered by [[Rosatom]].<ref name="edelstein">Nadezhda Kutepova & Olga Tsepilova, "A short history of the ZATO", pp. 148–149, in ''Cultures of Contamination, Volume 14: Legacies of Pollution in Russia and the US'' (Research in Social Problems and Public Policy), editors Michael Edelstein, Maria Tysiachniouk, Lyudmila V. Smirnova. JAI Press, 2007. {{ISBN|0-7623-1371-4}}</ref> Another 15 or so closed cities are believed to exist, but their names and locations have not been publicly disclosed by the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]].<ref name="kaser">Greg Kaser, "Motivation and Redirection: Rationale and Achievements in the Russian Closed Nuclear Cities", p. 3, in ''Countering Nuclear and Radiological Terrorism'', editors David J. Diamond, Samuel Apikyan, Greg Kaser. Springer, 2006. {{ISBN|1-4020-4897-1}}</ref>
Some Russian closed cities are open for foreign [[investment]], but foreigners may only enter with a [[license|permit]]. An example is the [[Nuclear Cities Initiative]] (NCI), a joint effort of the [[United States]] [[National Nuclear Security Administration]] and Minatom, which involves in part the cities of Sarov, Snezhinsk, and Zheleznogorsk.
The number of closed cities has been significantly reduced since the mid-1990s. However, on 30 October 2001, foreign travel (without any exceptions) was restricted in the northern cities of [[Norilsk]], [[Talnakh]], [[Kayerkan]], [[Dudinka]], and [[Igarka]]. Russian and Belarusian citizens visiting these cities are not required to have any permits, however, local courts are known to deport Belarusian citizens<ref>[http://ru-antivisa.livejournal.com/351602.html]</ref> in contradiction with federal Constitution.
[[Krasnoyarsk-26]] in Siberia, researched for the subject of [[Sidney Sheldon]]'s 2001 fictional murder mystery-romance ''The Sky is Falling'',<ref>{{ISBN|0446610178}}, "The Sky is Falling", by Sidney Sheldon, 2001</ref> was planned in 2003 to be shut down by 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/russia/krasnoyarsk-26_nuc.htm|title=Krasnoyarsk-26|author=John Pike|publisher=|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> in co-operation with the U.S, and documented by their Natural Resources Defense Council,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://docs.nrdc.org/nuclear/files/nuc_01019501a_138.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214091141/http://docs.nrdc.org/nuclear/files/nuc_01019501a_138.pdf |archivedate=2010-12-14 |df= }}</ref> but actually closed in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/04/21/idUSL21449998|title=Russia closes Soviet-era weapons grade reactor|work=Reuters|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref>
The number of closed cities in [[Russia]] is defined by government decree (see links further). They include the following cities. Reasons for restrictions are denoted in the descriptions below.
